intro: Ypsilopus tricuspis, commonly known as the three-lobed ypsilopus, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its distinctive three-lobed leaves and showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist forest understories, preferring rich, well-drained soils. Its flowers, which bloom in late summer, are pollinated primarily by bees and other small insects. Due to habitat loss, Ypsilopus tricuspis is considered endangered and is of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
